text: This is Mewes. Mewes has a message for you: "I ♥ CREATIVITY" Isn't that nice?
"I love creativity." A positive message that no one (other than a cartoon villain) should have a problem with.
"It IS harder to create than to destroy. That's why cowards tend to choose the deuce." &emdash; Steve, "A Minecraft Movie"
We might disagree on what constitutes "creativity", but the sentiment is still there: "In the long run, it is better to create than to destroy."
Mewes is an original character, designed to be a mascot for creativity in all its possible forms.
"Use what talents you possess; the woods would be very silent if no birds sang there except those that sang best." &emdash; Henry Van Dyke

"In ancient Greek religion and mythology, the Muses were the inspirational goddesses of literature, science, and the arts… In modern figurative usage, a muse is a person who serves as someone's source of artistic inspiration." &emdash; From Wikipedia, "The largest and most-read reference work in history… written collaboratively by the people who use it."

The spelling of "Mewes" comes from Jason Mewes of "Jay and Silent Bob" fame, characters created by writer/director Kevin Smith, who also wrote the following: "Remember: It costs nothing to encourage an artist, and the potential benefits are staggering. A pat on the back to an artist now could one day result in your favorite film, or the cartoon you love to get stoned watching, or the song that saves your life. Discourage an artist, you get absolutely nothing in return, ever."
(Pictured: Serendipity, the Muse, From Kevin Smith's "Dogma")
"Art isn't in the tools, material, or equipment you use. It's in the way you see the world." &emdash; Rick Rubin

Mewes is not a human, but instead, some sort of common rodent: a mouse or a rat. Mice and rats are highly adaptable and resourceful. They are found in nearly every wild environment on nearly every continent on Earth. And despite our best efforts and technology, they thrive among virtually every human habitation (including the Antarctica research station). With our help, rodents have even left Earth and orbited the Moon. We have treated them as harmful vermin, lovable pets, and model organisms in experimental research. Mice and rats are as ubiquitous to humanity as creativity is.

In the Chinese zodiac, the rat or mouse is associated with creativity, intelligence, and ambition. In fiction, mice and rats have been used to portray both positive and negative characters. Among them are some interesting representations of cunning, intelligence, wisdom, imagination, innovation, mischievousness, and courage: Algernon, Basil, Despereaux, Fievel, Jerry, Matthias, Mrs. [F/B]risby and the Rats of NIMH, Pinky and The Brain, Remy, Splinter, and Stuart Little…

…Not to mention one of the most popular and recognizable cartoon characters in the world… The first cartoon character to have a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame… The driving force behind decades of questionable changes to public domain and copyright laws… And the mascot of the world's largest media conglomerate… is a mouse named Mickey.
(Steamboat Willie, Directed by Walt Disney and Ub Iwerks, Released November 18, 1928, Entered the US public domain on January 1, 2024)

Even Mewes' visual design takes the greater concept of creativity into account: The design is simple &emdash; something that can be expanded with further details, but is still easy for a beginner to replicate. Research has confirmed that mice have a range of facial expressions associated with familiar human emotions like pleasure, disgust, pain, and fear. And the modern iconic image of creativity, imagination, inspiration, and ideation is the light bulb.
With all of this in mind, I believe Mewes makes the perfect mascot to promote all forms of creativity. BUT… I do see a problem…

"Is this just some scheme to gain popularity or get rich quickly by creating and promoting some viral internet meme?" you may be asking. A valid concern, especially if you and I disagree on certain views.

To allay such apprehensions, as well as to demonstrate my wider views regarding creativity, I am going to cast a sort of magic spell. It's a fairly simple procedure, one that anyone can perform on their own work. And it only requires three familiar runes…
CC0

From the Creative Commons website: "By marking the work with a CC0 public domain dedication, the creator is giving up their copyright and allowing reusers to distribute, remix, adapt, and build upon the material in any medium or format, even for commercial purposes."

"The person who associated a work with this deed has dedicated the work to the public domain by waiving all of his or her rights to the work worldwide under copyright law, including all related and neighboring rights, to the extent allowed by law."
"You can copy, modify, distribute, and perform the work, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission."

In other words, Mewes is no longer my property to control. (They don't even have to be called "Mewes" anymore) You can take this drawing &emdash; even the entire character concept &emdash; and do whatever you want with it: Print and distribute copies; Put it on your website or social media; Redraw it in your own style; Copy the existing style; Make physical or digital models of it; Generate AI images with it; Make a comic or animation with it; Sell merchandise or other products with it; All without obtaining my permission. There is nothing that can legally stop you.

You can even simply erase the message on their sign and have them promote ANY ideology you want them to: "SUPPORT HUMAN ARTISTS"; "AI ART IS ART"; "PICK UP A PENCIL"; "SELL OUT WITH ME TONIGHT"; Whose views do YOU want Mewes to represent in the greater culture?

I am prepared to create versions of Mewes that are: 2D and/or 3D; Physical and/or Digital; Visual, Aural, and/or Tactile; Still and/or Animated; Manual (hand-placed) and/or Procedural (rule-generated); Authorial (fully intentional) and/or Aleatory (chance-driven); Passive, Scripted, Dynamic, and/or Manipulated; Additive, Subtractive, and/or Assemblage; Direct (original medium) and/or Transfer (printed/copied); Discrete (pixel, voxel, polygon), Continuous (volumetric/CAD), and/or Mathematical (vectors, splines); Finalized and/or Instructional; Exportable in any format and shareable without restriction
"All technologies are neutral. What counts is who uses them and what they use them for. Any material, any tool in the hands of an artist, can result in a work of art." &emdash; Ken Robinson

I am prepared to create versions of Mewes that are: Realistic, Stylized, and/or Symbolic; Outlined, Lineless, and/or Implied; Binary, Monochrome, Limited Palette, and/or Full Color; Flat, Shaded, and/or Textured; Organic and/or Geometric; Culturally-Rooted, Cross-Cultural, and/or Synthesized; Iconic/Pictographic and/or Expressive/Idiosyncratic; Vintage and/or Modern; Naturalistic/Literal and/or Fantastic/Surreal; Feel free to create versions of Mewes in your own preferred methods, mediums, styles, techniques, or formats&emdash; and share them if you wish!

"There is no such thing as a new idea. It is impossible. We simply take a lot of old ideas and put them into a sort of mental kaleidoscope. We give them a turn, and they make new and curious combinations. We keep on turning and making new combinations indefinitely, but they are the same old pieces of colored glass that have been in use through all the ages." &emdash; Mark Twain
"Artists are the people among us who realize creation didn't stop on the sixth day." &emdash; Joel-Peter Witkin
